sentences.sentence: Canada's competition laws leave us ill-equipped to deal(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/opinion-why-our-toothless-competition-bureau-cant-go-after-big-tech) with the problems we face in the digital era.

In fact, our laws have historically been ill-equipped to address competition issues across all sorts of sectors - a structural problem that needs to be addressed.Parliament is contemplating reviewing the Competition Act sometime this spring.
If we want to make positive reforms, lawmakers need to reconsider the underlying philosophy that informs out competition policies.

The best way to understand the core deficiencies in Canadian competition law is to review what is articulated through cases that the Competition Bureau has taken under review.Former Competition Bureau commissioner John Pecman(https://www.fasken.com/en/john-pecman/#sort=%40fclientworksortdate75392%20descending) has said that Canada(https://thetyee.ca/News/2019/03/19/Monopoly-Friendly-Canada-Competition-Policy/) "does not treat competition policy seriously," and tolerates high corporate concentration in an effort to be competitive internationally.

He has even lamented that the bureau lacks the kind of independence that could make it more effective.Canada's current approach to competition policy is unique because of its relentless emphasis on promoting economic efficiency(https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/01954.html) - even at the cost of consumers and competitiveness.
This preference is exemplified by the fact that Canada routinely uses the "efficiencies defence" to justify corporate mergers, even if the merger threatens to undermine competition.

As long as the firms can show that the merger will create sufficiently large efficiencies, it will be legal under the Competition Act.Superior Propane's 1998 acquisition of ICG Propane is the most infamous example of the efficiencies defence in action.

Because the transaction was expected to create about $20 million in cost savings per year, Superior was permitted to acquire ICG, creating a monopoly in the retail sale of propane in 16 communities, and increasing Superior Propane's market share to 80 per cent in an additional 32 towns and cities.

After the merger, Superior Propane made up about 70 per cent of the entire Canadian retail market for propane.Some scholars have hypothesized that Canada's competition policy privileges growth in order to achieve international competitiveness, while discounting the benefits of vigorous competition in domestic markets.
The Superior Propane case is demonstrative of the law's preference for economic growth over competition.

When applied to the digital context, under this logic, if Amazon were a Canadian firm, it's strategy of steamrolling rivals and partners(https://www.wsj.com/articles/amazon-competition-shopify-wayfair-allbirds-antitrust-11608235127) could be implicitly encouraged through the law's tolerance for dominance.Another characteristic of Canada's competition policy is its tolerance for comically low levels of competition.

This attitude is typified by the Competition Tribunal's recent decision to dismiss an application against the Vancouver Airport Authority(https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2019/11/competition-bureau-will-not-appeal-ruling-in-case-against-vancouver-airport-authority.html) (VAA), in which it ruled that the VAA wasn't decreasing competition with its decision to only allow two in-flight catering companies access to the airport.The VAA was worried that if a new caterer entered, one or both of its active caterers would leave the market and it would be stuck without any.
Its behaviour was deemed to be permissible.

In fact, the tribunal actually agreed that there would be too much competition if the policy were not in place.While this decision is certainly perplexing, it is emblematic of Canada's outdated approach to promoting competition.
Such an attitude could at least partially explain our country's apparent comfort with oligopolies in the telecommunications, airline and media sectors.

And when this same logic is applied to technology firms, this case confirms that our laws are generally supportive of large tech companies actively working to limit new entrants to the market.If we consider the VAA as a platform that can control the companies that participate in its marketplace, we are reminded of the Competition Bureau's comfort with active gate-keeping, as Google, for example, is commonly accused of doing with its dominant position in the online advertising business.Canada's competition policy cannot be relied on to address competition issues in the digital sphere, and beyond.

However, the Competition Bureau's successful case against the Toronto Real Estate Board (TREB) provides hope that even with the weak tools we currently have, the Competition Bureau can still take some action to address anti-competitive behaviours.In its assessment of the case, the Competition Tribunal found that TREB abused its dominant position by prohibiting real estate agents from publishing sales data online, among other restrictions on the use of its data.

The tribunal found that the main intention of these restrictions was to protect its members from "disruptive competition" in the form of online services that make home sales and pricing data available.The case is important because TREB's use of its data to stifle innovation in the market was seen as a threat to economic efficiency.

In this case, our obsession with efficiency played out in favour of home buyers in Toronto, as the prices of sold homes must now be made public, which introduces more transparency into the marketplace.This case shows that Canadian competition authorities do not necessarily view a firm's data as proprietary, which could have important implications in the digital sphere, including in the areas of portability and interoperability.The growing enthusiasm for a review of the Competition Act is not merely motivated by the ambition for Canadian authorities to mirror existing cases against Amazon, Google or Facebook.

Indeed, Canada may not need to mimic these cases in order to benefit from their spillover effects.Rather, we need our policy toolkit to promote the responsible governance of digital firms of all sizes and protect consumers from anti-competitive behaviours.

As it stands, privileging economic efficiency and tolerating meagre amounts of competition is a weird and outdated strategy that reinforces the dominance of Big Tech, instead of questioning it.National PostVass Bednar is the executive director of McMaster University's master of public policy in digital society program.

Robin Shaban is principal at Vivic Research, an economic consulting firm that provides data-driven research for policymakers and advocates.Opinion: When it comes to Big Tech, Canada's fighting 21st-century battles with 20th-century weapons(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/opinion-when-it-comes-to-big-tech-canadas-fighting-21st-century-battles-with-20th-century-weapons)Opinion: Why Canada's toothless Competition Bureau can't go after Big Tech(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/opinion-why-our-toothless-competition-bureau-cant-go-after-big-tech) !
